moves.3. dxe5 Ng4 4. e4: I could have hung onto it, but I sensed that this is one of those gambits where black usually gets his pawn back. I could be wrong though.
moves.4... Nxe5 5. Bf4 Qf6 6. Bxe5 Qxe5 7. Nc3: And we're left with a rather interesting position. My development is superior and I have better central control, but he has the potential for a quick attack...
moves.11... Bh3 12. Nh4 Qg5 13. Kh1: I thought this was best. I end up down a pawn and there's a clear breach in my king's wall of pawns, but at least I'm only down a pawn.
moves.13... Qxh4 14. gxh3 Qxh3: Things are looking pretty bad for white now...
moves.15. Bg4 Qh6 16. Rc2 d5: Hm... I'm not sure I like this, it allows my to connect my pawns.
moves.17. cxd5: I think this capture was best.
moves.17... Bd6: Oh... So that's why the sacrificed a pawn. Well I don't think this is worth it. Although it does allow him to regain his pawn.
moves.18. f4 g6: ? He should have taken my pawn. Now I have an imposing wall of pawns aimed at him.
moves.19... Bc5: And... Force him into a more active square. But that doesn't really matter now as I have the initiative. His queen, once a danger is now out of place and incapable of helping defend. My queen offers support to the d file.
moves.20. e6: Trying to force open a file.
moves.20... fxe6 21. Bxe6: I had to think about it, but I thought this was best.
moves.21... Bd6 22. Rcf2 Na6 23. Re1: He *could* take my pawn but I wouldn't...
moves.23... Qh4: This is good... Brings his queen into a more active position and offers defense to e7.
moves.26... Ke7 27. Bg8+: This time, the bishop blocks the rook's defense. Actually, he can't retake my rook because then he'd be a mating net.
